block.name: [CyberRadio] NDR Driver Interface
block.make: CyberRadio.NDR_driver_interface( radio_type=$radio_type, verbose=$verbose, #if $log_file_block() != "" log_file=self.$(log_file_block()), #else log_file=$log_file, #end if connect_mode=$connect_mode, #if $connect_mode() == "tty" dev_name=$dev_name, baud_rate=$baud_rate, #else if $connect_mode() in ["tcp", "udp"] host_name=$host_name, host_port=$host_port, #end if )
block.doc:
The NDR_driver_interface block allows GNU Radio applications to \ access the CyberRadio Solutions NDR Driver to configure an NDR-class \ radio and query its capabilities. The block supports all of the \ methods from the Driver's IRadio interface; the results of those \ methods depend on which radio is being targeted.
The Radio Type field defines what type of NDR radio we are interested in. \ This field should be one of the name strings defined by the \ Driver. The Driver documentation lists which name strings are supported.
Verbose mode determines how much logging data the Driver produces.
The Log File field is a file-like object that handles logging output from \ the Driver. Setting this to None will disable log output entirely (unless \ the Log File Block field is used -- see below).
The Log File Block field is the name of another block in this flowgraph \ that can act as a file-like object for collecting logging output (such as \ the File-Like Object Source block). If this field is filled in, then the \ Log File field will be ignored.
The Connection Mode specifies how user code connects to the radio. \ This can be either no connection, TCP, UDP, or TTY (serial link). \ Note that different radios support different connection modes. See \ the Driver documentation for details.
For radios supporting TTY connections, the Radio Device Name and Radio \ Baud Rate provide the parameters for the serial connection. For radios \ supporting TCP or UDP connections, the Radio Host Name and Radio Host \ Port provide the parameters for the network link to the radio.
